title: Is a game just a game?
intro: Computer games might be fun but are they good for you? Listen to Rob and Finn discussing whether adult computer games could affect our children’s health. They also explain some of the words connected to this topic.
this_week_question: What percentage of people who play computer games are female? Is it...
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: suited to your tastes or abilities
a film, TV programme or computer game that has a lot of shooting and violence
not able or not likely to cause harm
showing things in an open and direct way
not the right thing for a particular situation
other groups of people, such as friends, relatives and teachers

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob...

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: ...and I'm Finn. Hello.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Rob Hello, Finn. Did you have a good weekend?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Yeah, it was OK thanks although, you know, I'm a bit tired now.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Why's that?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: It's a bit embarrassing but I stayed up all night playing a computer game.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: All night?! You must be addicted. Addicted , by the way, means unable to stop doing something.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, maybe today's programme might have some advice for me.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's right. Today we're discussing whether computer games are bad for our health - and in particular - bad for children.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: OK, Rob, why don't you wake me up a little bit by asking me today's quiz question?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK - here goes. In America, what percentage of people who play computer games are female? Is it...

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, I do know a few female gamers so how about b) 38%.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, right. Go for the middle option? We'll find out if that's the right answer later on. OK, so what kind of computer games do you like to play, Finn?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, I quite like those role-playing games. You know, the fantasy role-playing games.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, well, role playing is where you create your own characters and stories in a fantasy - or imaginary - world. But, to be honest, those kind of games aren't really up my alley - which means they're not really suited to my tastes or abilities. Any other kind of games you like, Finn?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Yeah, I also quite like shoot-'em-up games. These are games where you have to do a lot of shooting and there's a lot of violence.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: It's funny because you don't strike me as a violent person, Finn.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: I'm not, at all. I wouldn't hurt a fly, Rob! But maybe shooting people on a computer screen seems a bit more harmless.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. And not to hurt a fly means to be gentle and unwilling to make people unhappy. And harmless means unlikely to hurt or upset anyone. Well, let's hear Internet safety advisor Alan MacKenzie discussing how adult computer games can have a negative effect on children.

transcript.author: Alan MacKenzie, internet safety advisor
transcript.text: Many people understandably will just think that a game is just a game and not realising the explicit content that's in there - and as you suggest, the violence and sexualisation of women in particular, which is wholly inappropriate for anybody, never mind children.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, you know, if you want my opinion, Rob, a game is just a game. It's generally a harmless form of entertainment. What do you think?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I'm torn , actually - meaning I'm unable to decide. Most people, like you Finn, probably aren't affected by what you see in computer games. But we can't ignore the small percentage of people who are affected.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Well, that's true really, isn't it, Rob? And whilst playing computer games all night doesn't make me violent, it certainly makes me very tired!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I can see that. But also Finn - when do you and your wife actually talk to each other - when you're in your own computer fantasy world for hours on end?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Yeah, it's not great, is it? And for hours on end means a long time, by the way! So, I don't know. Maybe if she played as well, then we could have some virtual conversations...

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, that sounds ridiculous! But let's move on. Alan talks about explicit content in games. What does that mean?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: That means showing things in an open and direct way. So some adult games contain open violence and sexualisation.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And shall we explain what sexualisation means?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Yes. It means making someone or something sexual - and in this case, women. This might be through the shape of a woman's body, or the clothes she wears, or the way she behaves in these games.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Alan says this type of explicit content - violent or sexual - is inappropriate for computer games. And inappropriate means not the right thing for a particular situation.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: And he is worried about children accessing this type of content. Let's hear more from him. What advice does he give?

transcript.author: Alan MacKenzie, internet safety advisor
transcript.text: So it's a matter of educating the parents and the wider community in these issues, and making them aware of the type of content that's in there, and why it's inappropriate, and the effects that it may be having on their children and their behaviour.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Alan thinks it's the responsibility of parents and the wider community - now that means other groups of people, such as friends, relatives and teachers for example - to check on what children are viewing and playing.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But this will only work if they understand which types of content are OK and which aren't.

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: That's right. So the adults need educating too. They need to be shown.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, that's right. So I'll be checking on your behaviour from now on, Finn!

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: OK, That's probably a good idea. So, let's hear the answer to today's quiz question next.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes and I asked you, in America, what percentage of people who play computer games are female? Is it... a) 28% b) 38% or c) 48%?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: And I went for the middle option, as usual, and I said b) 38%.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And you are wrong, this time Finn! The answer is actually c) 48%. Are you surprised by that?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Yes and no. I think a lot more people are playing games in general, so lots of them must be women.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Absolutely. Why not? OK, shall we now listen to the words we learned today?

transcript.author: Finn
transcript.text: Good idea. We heard:

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Thank you. Well, that brings us to the end of today's 6 Minute English. We hope you enjoyed today's programme. You can hear other 6 Minute English programmes at bbclearningenglish.com . Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
